messageBody:
On 5/11/07, J. B. Rainsberger <jbrains762@...> wrote:
>
>
>
>
>
>
> Alexandru Popescu ☀ wrote:
>
> > JMock 2.x (this one is imo a mess: they
> > moved from string-based method invocation to more static approach, but they
> > have completely screwed the API)
>
> I think there is a lot of strong opinion, both positive and negative, to
> the JMock 2 API. Smalltalkers and Rubyists love it, others hate it. It's
> the most creative use of Java I've ever seen and if the API fails, I
> blame Java, not JMock.
>
> From their web site:
>
> context.checking(new Expectations() {{
> one (subscriber).receive(message);
> }});
>
> subscriber is the mock object whose expecting receive(message) once. The
> punctuation is ugly, but the words are beautiful. If it were this,
> wouldn't it be nearly perfect?
>
> context.checking expectations [
> one: subscriber.receive(message);
> ]

Probably. And you have presented only the first code line from the
example, which is still unreadable: one(subscriber): does mean in fact
that subscriber will receive ONE message and not what the english
reading of that code implies. And this is clear once you are using the
other methods.
The following lines of the sample are becoming even more readable as
they are completely disconnected from the previous. Comparing this
with:

expect(myobject.doSomething()).andReturn()

I still find this last one more readable. But, I have to agree this is
more a matter of taste, and so I will not argue on (in fact I said it
from the beginning that my ranking is a matter of taste and experience
with these frameworks and not something I am absolute about).

bests,
